awd_titl_txt: Dissecting molecular mechanisms of plant cytokinesis and cell plate development
awd_abstract_narration:
This interdisciplinary project will increase the understanding of how plant cells divide. During plant cell division the formation of a novel structure, the cell plate which evolves into the new cell wall, separates the new daughter cells.  The development of new cell walls during cell division is of profound importance to all plant life on earth, yet fundamental questions about this process remain unanswered. This project focuses on dissecting   the highly dynamic process of cell plate formation by employing quantitative image analysis, computational modeling, biochemistry and genetics coupled with chemical inhibition of key players in cell division. The work should prove transformative, be applicable to a broad variety of plant species and hence contribute to both fundamental research and the development of more desirable cell wall properties for robust and productive crops. Overall, the work could form the basis for new strategies towards improving crop quality and yield, towards increasing food security and towards energy independence.  The produced models and animations of cell plate formation will be made widely available for free educational use. The project will provide research training across a broad range of cutting-edge research methodologies in modern cell biology for junior scientists at the high school, undergraduate, graduate and postgraduate level. Graduate students and postdocs will develop mentoring and teaching skills supervising high school and undergraduate students through the framework of this project.  

The overarching goal of this project is to identify and quantitatively analyze new molecular mechanisms and pathways directing polysaccharide cargo during cell plate formation in cytokinesis, a process fundamental to all plant life on earth. Cytokinesis in plants is fundamentally different from that in animals and fungi. In plants de novo formation of a cell plate occurs via homotypic fusion of vesicles, which then develops into the new cell wall, partitioning the cytoplasm of the dividing cell. Cell plate formation takes place in multiple stages that involve highly orchestrated vesicle accumulation, fusion and membrane maturation concurrent with the time specific deposition of polysaccharides such as callose, cellulose and cross-linking glycans.   The project will use quantitative fluorescence imaging during cytokinesis to develop a spatiotemporal model of cell plate formation. Further, the use of biochemical, and genetic approaches combined with chemical biology will help in characterizing the polysaccharide components building the new cell wall during cytokinesis and identify novel molecular players involved in cell plate development. These studies will generate fundamental knowledge of mechanisms that control cell plate assembly and can form a reference framework for cell wall build up.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During plant cell division, a novel structure called the cell plate forms and eventually develops into the new cell wall that separates the daughter cells. Cell plate formation involves a highly orchestrated process of vesicle accumulation, fusion, and membrane network maturation, supported by the deposition of polysaccharides, including the flexible callose. The development of the new cell wall during cell division is profoundly important to all plant life on Earth, yet it remains poorly understood.

Dissecting cell plate development requires imaging modalities capturing the dynamic behavior of cytokinetic vesicles throughout this process. Exploring lattice light sheet microscopy (LLSM), we studied for the first time the entire cell plate development across four dimensions (4D)—from its first emergence, via cytokinesis specific GTPase YFP-RABA2a vesicles to the fully developed cell wall. We identified and quantitatively described three distinct and trackable, cell plate developmental phases. The phase transition between phase I and II is striking, marking a shift from membrane accumulation to the recycling of excess membrane material. Furthermore, treatment with the cytokinetic-specific callose deposition inhibitor Endosidin7 (ES7), suppressed phase transitions, highlighting the critical timing and role of callose deposition in cell plate expansion and maturation. This study exemplifies the power of LLSM together with quantitative image analysis to untangle such a complex process.

In parallel, we observed and studied the distinct ring-like deposition pattern of callose at the division plane of the unicellular alga Penium margaritaceum, demonstrating that cytokinetic callose deposition is evolutionarily conserved and not restricted to multicellular plant species.

The mechanisms underlying the complex transition from a vesicle membrane network to a mature cell plate were investigated using biophysical modeling. We approximated cell plate sub-structures with testable shapes and adopted a free energy model for membranes, including a stabilizing and spreading force, to understand the transition from a vesicular network to a fenestrated sheet and mature cell plate. The model predicts that a spreading/stabilizing force is vital for cell plate expansion and maturation. We further showed that in the absence of a spreading/stabilizing force, the addition of membrane material yields stable membrane network structures that do not transition into a mature cell plate. Based on our experimental observations, the transiently accumulating callose during cell plate maturation is likely the main factor in establishing the spreading force.

Our imaging approach, along with the quantitative analysis and data integration into the model provides a framework for understanding how membrane structures evolve and will likely be adopted in investigations of similar transitions, beyond that of cytokinesis.

Endomembrane transport is a finely regulated process, with the trans-Golgi network (TGN) serving as the dominant operational hub in the cell. However, the specifics of how matrix polysaccharides (hemicelluloses, pectins and glycoproteins) that are made in the Golgi apparatus are transported to and integrated into the cell wall are still largely unknown. To better understand the regulation of plant cell wall construction, we investigated the glycan contents of specific subsets of TGN vesicles by combining vesicle isolation and glycomics. This approach provided insights into the structure and types of wall polysaccharides within the endomembrane system before their deposition in the apoplast. Based on these data, hypotheses can be formulated and explored regarding the biosynthesis of specific matrix polysaccharides in the endomembrane system and their modifications during cell wall assembly.

Additionally, we identified a novel regulator of plant endomembrane trafficking, AtTRAPPC11, which defines the plant-specific TRAPPIII tethering complex. This regulator plays a crucial role in maintaining the organization of the TGN and is involved in post-Golgi trafficking as well as the plant stress response.

Cumulatively, knowledge from this research impacts long-term applications, forming frameworks for strategies in modifying plant characteristics for improved nutritional value and plant stress responses.

To effectively communicate our findings and the complex process of plant cytokinesis to the public, we developed an animation that was met with enthusiasm by diverse audiences and is freely available.

Through this project, postdocs, graduate students, high school students, high school teachers, international visiting scholars, and undergraduate students were trained and mentored. This research became a core component of the PLS100AL undergraduate laboratory course, where students explored live confocal cell imaging and chemical biology.

In addition, elements of this research were shared with the local community through presentations at colleges, high schools, science fairs, and local science venues, as well as at science communication forums.
